How to design a gelatin-based material by optimizing the concentration of the redox couple ([Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻/[Fe(CN)₆]³⁻) to enhance its thermoelectric performance (thermopower), while maintaining good mechanical properties and ionic conductivity, thereby achieving efficient thermoelectric conversion?

By testing a A matrix of gelatin with 0.8 M KCl soaked in a solution of 0.42 M K₄[Fe(CN)₆] and 0.25 M K₃[Fe(CN)₆], and measuring its thermopower under a temperature gradient using copper electrodes (Cu | i-TE | Cu), the high concentration of [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻/[Fe(CN)₆]³⁻ will significantly enhance the Seebeck effect and charge transfer efficiency. The flexibility of the gelatin matrix and the high ionic conductivity of KCl will make this system suitable for efficient thermoelectric conversion while maintaining mechanical stability.

The flexibility of the gelatin matrix and the high ionic conductivity of KCl will make this system suitable for efficient thermoelectric conversion while maintaining mechanical stability.

By testing a A matrix of gelatin with 0.8 M KCl soaked in a solution of 0.08 M K₄[Fe(CN)₆] and 0.05 M K₃[Fe(CN)₆], and measuring its thermopower under a temperature gradient using copper electrodes (Cu | i-TE | Cu), the low concentration of the [Fe(CN)₆]⁴⁻/[Fe(CN)₆]³⁻ redox couple will enhance thermopower due to the introduction of redox-mediated charge transfer. The high ionic strength of KCl (0.8 M) will further support ionic conductivity, while the gelatin matrix maintains mechanical stability and flexibility.

The gelatin matrix is expected to provide good mechanical flexibility and biocompatibility, but its thermoelectric performance may be limited due to the absence of redox-mediated charge transfer.
